MEDICAL NOTICE.

SHOCKING AccIDENT.-W We have seen letter
from young gentleman at Northampton, TO his
father in this city, giving melancholy account Of
the upset,irg Of the mail stage from Albany TO
Northampton within five or six miles Of the latter
place, about o'clock on the evening of Thursday
last. There were eight passengers inside, and one,
young man. son Of the Rev MIR. Tower Of
MiburY, on the outside with the driver. The drives
and MIR. Tower were thrown from the seat to a
ledge OF rocks. The driver died in about an hour |;
MIR. Tower lived ill 9 o'clock next morning. The
rest Of the passengers were much bruised Only
two of them were men, one Of whom had his leg
broken. The other six, women and children, we're
more or less injured. The collar bone of one was
much fractured The driver never spoke after he
was taken up, and the young man who was thrown
from the seat with him, was unable 10 give any &C
From the Boston Courier, Dec. 10.

e extract The following happ, version of the Le
er from g Devohonal Perses," By BERNARD BART
FATHER of all who dwell'st above,
Thy name be hallowed here;
Asin those realms of peace and love,
Where saints that name revere.
Thy kingdom come; thy will, alone,
BE done by man below;
As spirits round thy glorious throne,
Their pure obedience show.
Give us this day our daily breads


No; merely outward food.
But that whereon the soul is fed,
The source Of heavenly good.
Forgive our trespasses, asw


In parloning love abide
Since none forgiveness win from thee
Who pardon have denied
And lead us from temptation far


From evil, Lord, restores
For thine the power, the kingdom, are,
The glory evermore!
THE LORDS PRAYER.

STORY OF AMPATO SAPA.


This beautiful spot in the Mississippi, Falls o
s.. Anthony, is not without tale to hallow its see
merry, and heighten the interest, which, OF ITSELF l
is calculated to produce. 10 Wazekots, an old In
dian, We are indebted for the narration OF the fol
lowing transaction, TO which his mother was ar
eye witness. An Indian of the Decato nation hat
united himself early in life TO youthful female
whose name was Ampato Sapa, which signifies the
dark day; with her he lived happily for severa
years, apparently enjoying every comfort which the
savage life afford. Their union had been blessed
with two children, on whom both parents doated with
that depth Of feeling which is unknown to such a. have
other besides those that spring from nature
The man had acquired reputation as a hunter
which drew around him many families, who were
happy TO plece themselves under his protection, and
avail themselves oi such part Of his chase as he
needed not for the maintenance Of his own family
Desirous of strengthening their interests with him
some Of them invited him to form connexon with
their family, observing at the same time, that
man Of his talent and importance required more
than one woman TO wait upon the numerous guests
whom his reputation would induce 10 visit his lodge
They assured him that he would soon be acknow
edged as chief, and thAt in this case, second wife
was indispensable. Fired with the ambition OF OBJ
tanning high honors he resolved TO increase his i'm
porance BY an union with the daughte OF an inhn
ensial man OF his tribe. He had accordingly taker
second wife, without having ever mentioned tbs
subject to his former companion. Being desiroui
to introduce his bride into his lodge, in the manne
which should be least offensive to the mother Of hi
children, for whom he still retained much regard
he introduced the subject in these words: Yot
know said he, that can love no woman so fond
" as doat upon you. With regret, | have sect
you, of lale subjected to tolls, which must be op
pr~ssive to you, and from which would gladly re
lievc you yet know no other way OF doing SO
than BY associa,ng to you 10 the household dntie
one who shall relieve you from the trouble OF en-
tertaining the numerous guests, whom my growing
| importance in the nation collects around me.
have therefore resolved upon taking another vile
but she shall always be subject TO your CONTROL a
she will always rank in my affections second to you
| With the utmost anxiety, and the deepest concerr
did his companion listen to this unexpected proPo
SAL She expostulated in the kindest terms, er
treated him with all the arguments which undi:
guised love and the purest conjugal affection coul
suggest. She replied to sll the objections whic
his dupliciiy led him TO raise. DESTROYS OF wnn'r
her from her opposition, The Indian slil concealt
The secret nf his union with another, while she r,
doubled all her care to convince him that she WI
equal to the task imposed upon her. When I
again spoke upon the subject she pleaded all the e
ldearmen,s Of her past life; she spoke OF his iorm
fondncss for her OF his regard for her hsppine
and thar OF their mutual offspring she bads hi
beware OF the consequences OF this fatal purpose
his Finding her bent upon Withholding her conse
TO his plan, he informed her that all opposition
her part was unnecessary he had already selects
another partner; and tina, If she could not see h
lnew wife as 4 friend, she must receive her as n
cessary ncumbrance for he had resolved ste shot
be an inmate OF his house. Distressed q, this no
nation, she watched her opportunity. and stole avn
from the cabin with her infants, and fed to dstan
where her father was. With him she reman
until party Of Indians with whom he lived We
up the Mississippi to hunt In the spring, as tn
were returning with their canoes, loaded with pc
tries, they encamped near the falls. In the NOR
ing as they left it, she fingered Eesr the spot, III
launched her light canoe, entered into It with
Children and padded down the stream singing b
death. song. Too late did her friends perceive
their attempts to prevent her from proceeding we
OF no avail she was heard TO sing, in dole


voice, the past pleasures which she had enjoy
while she was the undivided object OF her HUSBAND
:. affection finally her voice was drowned n
!. sound OF the cataract the current carried down
= = frail bark with nconceivable rapidly; 1t came
the edge Of the precipice, was seen for . moms
enveloped with spray, but never afer was trace


the canoe or its passengers seen. Yet it is stat


by the Indians that often in the morning 20
i. had been heard to sing doiefu dilty along


edge Of the fall and that ii dwells ever upon the
eonstancy Of her husband. Nay. one sssett 4
her spirit had been wandering near the 81
with her children wrapped TO her bosom. ,, ch
= the tales or traditions which the indians treasure
- and which they relate to the voyager. forcing i


from the eyes of the most relentless.


- s5J5Jt,

Extracts from the Message of Coz. KENr to the


General assembly Of Maryland, Dec. eth, 1896.
| Immediately upon the adoption Of the resolutions
appointing "a joint committee consisting OF one
me einber from the senate, and two [mem6ers) from
the house OF delegates to visit the legislatures OF
Pennsyyania, New-Jersey and Delaware TO confer
with those bodies, respectively, upon the measures
best calculated to prevent the absconding OF slaes
from this state, and OF securing their recovery, -
being informed BY the gentlemen constituting the
committee tina, they would set out without delay up
on the mission we addressed letter to the COVER
nor Of each of the said states copy whereof 10
herewith submitted, together with The report OF the
committre, which has Just been received.


BY this report and the accompanying documents,
We have the qualification to 6nd that with the legis-
latures OF Delaware and Pennsylvania. the commit
Ice SuCCCCuCu H. ObtoHil6 PnsoabS " o"o "Sia
calculated TO effect the very important objects OF
their mission.


The legislature Of New Jersey not beiog in ses-
sion until lately, No opportunity was afforded OF ma
king to it. personal explanation Of the purposes
OF their mission, Of the enac!ments believed ne
css..ry to accomplish them But thnt1rll1nR6s a
written communication to ~


nor of that state. "a co


documents accompany suiiy disc'0-
sing in a lucid and 1ds eeVH1fner, their views OF


the whole subject, with request that It DC submlt-
ted 10 the legislature and we entertain the fullest
confidence. that that enlightened body will be found
animated by the same just and liberal spirit which
guided her sister states, and that during lis present


session law will be passed equally satisfactory with
those of Delaware and Pennsylvania.


| We scarcely know which most 10 commend, the


ability with which the committee supported their


application or the enlightened and lneral spirit in


which they were received, and the sense OF justice


and good feelings tha, enabled them so fully to sue
, coed in securing the objects Of their mission.
BY virtue Of the resolution, No. 20, We selected


and employed the Hon. William Writ. attorney
general Of the United States, and Roger b. Taney,


Esquire 10 appear the suit which had been nsti-
ued, snd was pending in the Supreme Court oil


the United States against citizens OF this sta c, Tor
afrearsgrs Of qui. rents claimed BY the adminstra
ton OF Louisa Browning, heir at law OF a former
u proprietary whilst Maryland was British province.





SUIT against the venerable Charles Carroll Of Car"
rollton, now the only su,viyng sgner OF the Deca-
ration Of Independence, Thy the establishment OF


which, in our opinion. the claim was forever barred
and off,r was brought to an issue IN March last,
: and the Judgment nt the Supreme Court finally
y pronounced against the claimant, upon principles
that apply TO- and protec, every andholder in Mary
d land. The pretended claim of the representatives
t of Mrs Browning, may therefore be considered as
at rest and the andholders OF the state freed from


any further vcxaon thereby.


The high importance OF the principles involved
in the claim as well as It's great amount indu' ed
r us to select two oil the mos, eminent members OF
r the legal profe sion resist il, and we are ath-
ed 10 learn tina, they fully sustained that occasion,
c their exalted regulations"


VI THAT the Peneniary system, as ours is at Pres
ID en-, organized, has tailed in greet degree, as a
means oil refo, maiion both here and elsewhere is
le updenable. Notwithstanding which, every effort
sr should be made 10 periecti ard 10 ascertain "e'h
er our disappointed hopes have ded from ally

OF or from tho settled depravity Of human naue-de
ID fvins- the institutions of and TO be operated or
ce by the force Of Religion only The system nself
ne i. benevolent one Let Us then make the tx, er
Ne .n Of solitary conhncn eni, as recommended II
at the report Of the committee, and which has bccI
OF e.orted 10 by some OF sister siaes with sangun
re hopes Of success. Solitary confinement a, night
p, after day OF silence and labor is most painful 4
ar those wi,hou, mental resources; more especial.


when the mind i, destitute Of the recollection o


any actions bu, those of wi.kedness.


Should the legislature approve OF the eXperimep


heinz made sufficient number oil small cells coui
er be provided by means be derived from The peni
lis ten,iary itself.


Of We would further recommend TO the General As
to sembly the propriey Of so smending the law as
increase the punishment in all cases of second con
ay vic,ions and that some other punishment than con

full articles.headline: From the Boston Courier, Dec. 10.
full articles.article:
SHOCKING AccIDENT.-W We have seen letter
from young gentleman at Northampton, TO his
father in this city, giving melancholy account Of
the upset,irg Of the mail stage from Albany TO
Northampton within five or six miles Of the latter
place, about o'clock on the evening of Thursday
last. There were eight passengers inside, and one,
young man. son Of the Rev MIR. Tower Of
MiburY, on the outside with the driver. The drives
and MIR. Tower were thrown from the seat to a
ledge OF rocks. The driver died in about an hour |;
MIR. Tower lived ill 9 o'clock next morning. The
rest Of the passengers were much bruised Only
two of them were men, one Of whom had his leg
broken. The other six, women and children, we're
more or less injured. The collar bone of one was
much fractured The driver never spoke after he
was taken up, and the young man who was thrown
from the seat with him, was unable 10 give any &C

full articles.headline: THE LORDS PRAYER.
full articles.article:
e extract The following happ, version of the Le
er from g Devohonal Perses," By BERNARD BART
FATHER of all who dwell'st above,
Thy name be hallowed here;
Asin those realms of peace and love,
Where saints that name revere.
Thy kingdom come; thy will, alone,
BE done by man below;
As spirits round thy glorious throne,
Their pure obedience show.
Give us this day our daily breads


No; merely outward food.
But that whereon the soul is fed,
The source Of heavenly good.
Forgive our trespasses, asw


In parloning love abide
Since none forgiveness win from thee
Who pardon have denied
And lead us from temptation far


From evil, Lord, restores
For thine the power, the kingdom, are,
The glory evermore!

Rebuke.-pythagoras gave one Of his scholars a
reprimand in the presence of the rest which so Sc
riously affected him that he could not survive 1t, and
killed himself. Theuceforth Pythagoras. instruct
ed and infinitely afflicted by so mourniul an exam
pie, never rebuked any one except in private.

full articles.headline:
WILMINGTON, Del. FRIDAY, JANUARY 2s, 1927

FROM MAJOR LONGS EXPEDITION.
STORY OF AMPATO SAPA.
full articles.article:
STORY OF AMPATO SAPA.


This beautiful spot in the Mississippi, Falls o
s.. Anthony, is not without tale to hallow its see
merry, and heighten the interest, which, OF ITSELF l
is calculated to produce. 10 Wazekots, an old In
dian, We are indebted for the narration OF the fol
lowing transaction, TO which his mother was ar
eye witness. An Indian of the Decato nation hat
united himself early in life TO youthful female
whose name was Ampato Sapa, which signifies the
dark day; with her he lived happily for severa
years, apparently enjoying every comfort which the
savage life afford. Their union had been blessed
with two children, on whom both parents doated with
that depth Of feeling which is unknown to such a. have
other besides those that spring from nature
The man had acquired reputation as a hunter
which drew around him many families, who were
happy TO plece themselves under his protection, and
avail themselves oi such part Of his chase as he
needed not for the maintenance Of his own family
Desirous of strengthening their interests with him
some Of them invited him to form connexon with
their family, observing at the same time, that
man Of his talent and importance required more
than one woman TO wait upon the numerous guests
whom his reputation would induce 10 visit his lodge
They assured him that he would soon be acknow
edged as chief, and thAt in this case, second wife
was indispensable. Fired with the ambition OF OBJ
tanning high honors he resolved TO increase his i'm
porance BY an union with the daughte OF an inhn
ensial man OF his tribe. He had accordingly taker
second wife, without having ever mentioned tbs
subject to his former companion. Being desiroui
to introduce his bride into his lodge, in the manne
which should be least offensive to the mother Of hi
children, for whom he still retained much regard
he introduced the subject in these words: Yot
know said he, that can love no woman so fond
" as doat upon you. With regret, | have sect
you, of lale subjected to tolls, which must be op
pr~ssive to you, and from which would gladly re
lievc you yet know no other way OF doing SO
than BY associa,ng to you 10 the household dntie
one who shall relieve you from the trouble OF en-
tertaining the numerous guests, whom my growing
| importance in the nation collects around me.
have therefore resolved upon taking another vile
but she shall always be subject TO your CONTROL a
she will always rank in my affections second to you
| With the utmost anxiety, and the deepest concerr
did his companion listen to this unexpected proPo
SAL She expostulated in the kindest terms, er
treated him with all the arguments which undi:
guised love and the purest conjugal affection coul
suggest. She replied to sll the objections whic
his dupliciiy led him TO raise. DESTROYS OF wnn'r
her from her opposition, The Indian slil concealt
The secret nf his union with another, while she r,
doubled all her care to convince him that she WI
equal to the task imposed upon her. When I
again spoke upon the subject she pleaded all the e
ldearmen,s Of her past life; she spoke OF his iorm
fondncss for her OF his regard for her hsppine
and thar OF their mutual offspring she bads hi
beware OF the consequences OF this fatal purpose
his Finding her bent upon Withholding her conse
TO his plan, he informed her that all opposition
her part was unnecessary he had already selects
another partner; and tina, If she could not see h
lnew wife as 4 friend, she must receive her as n
cessary ncumbrance for he had resolved ste shot
be an inmate OF his house. Distressed q, this no
nation, she watched her opportunity. and stole avn
from the cabin with her infants, and fed to dstan
where her father was. With him she reman
until party Of Indians with whom he lived We
up the Mississippi to hunt In the spring, as tn
were returning with their canoes, loaded with pc
tries, they encamped near the falls. In the NOR
ing as they left it, she fingered Eesr the spot, III
launched her light canoe, entered into It with
Children and padded down the stream singing b
death. song. Too late did her friends perceive
their attempts to prevent her from proceeding we
OF no avail she was heard TO sing, in dole


voice, the past pleasures which she had enjoy
while she was the undivided object OF her HUSBAND
:. affection finally her voice was drowned n
!. sound OF the cataract the current carried down
= = frail bark with nconceivable rapidly; 1t came
the edge Of the precipice, was seen for . moms
enveloped with spray, but never afer was trace


the canoe or its passengers seen. Yet it is stat


by the Indians that often in the morning 20
i. had been heard to sing doiefu dilty along


edge Of the fall and that ii dwells ever upon the
eonstancy Of her husband. Nay. one sssett 4
her spirit had been wandering near the 81
with her children wrapped TO her bosom. ,, ch
= the tales or traditions which the indians treasure
- and which they relate to the voyager. forcing i


from the eyes of the most relentless.


- s5J5Jt,


From the Boston Courier Dec lo

Extracts from the Message of Coz. KENr to the


General assembly Of Maryland, Dec. eth, 1896.
| Immediately upon the adoption Of the resolutions
appointing "a joint committee consisting OF one
me einber from the senate, and two [mem6ers) from
the house OF delegates to visit the legislatures OF
Pennsyyania, New-Jersey and Delaware TO confer
with those bodies, respectively, upon the measures
best calculated to prevent the absconding OF slaes
from this state, and OF securing their recovery, -
being informed BY the gentlemen constituting the
committee tina, they would set out without delay up
on the mission we addressed letter to the COVER
nor Of each of the said states copy whereof 10
herewith submitted, together with The report OF the
committre, which has Just been received.


BY this report and the accompanying documents,
We have the qualification to 6nd that with the legis-
latures OF Delaware and Pennsylvania. the commit
Ice SuCCCCuCu H. ObtoHil6 PnsoabS " o"o "Sia
calculated TO effect the very important objects OF
their mission.


The legislature Of New Jersey not beiog in ses-
sion until lately, No opportunity was afforded OF ma
king to it. personal explanation Of the purposes
OF their mission, Of the enac!ments believed ne
css..ry to accomplish them But thnt1rll1nR6s a
written communication to ~


nor of that state. "a co


documents accompany suiiy disc'0-
sing in a lucid and 1ds eeVH1fner, their views OF


the whole subject, with request that It DC submlt-
ted 10 the legislature and we entertain the fullest
confidence. that that enlightened body will be found
animated by the same just and liberal spirit which
guided her sister states, and that during lis present


session law will be passed equally satisfactory with
those of Delaware and Pennsylvania.


| We scarcely know which most 10 commend, the


ability with which the committee supported their


application or the enlightened and lneral spirit in


which they were received, and the sense OF justice


and good feelings tha, enabled them so fully to sue
, coed in securing the objects Of their mission.
BY virtue Of the resolution, No. 20, We selected


and employed the Hon. William Writ. attorney
general Of the United States, and Roger b. Taney,


Esquire 10 appear the suit which had been nsti-
ued, snd was pending in the Supreme Court oil


the United States against citizens OF this sta c, Tor
afrearsgrs Of qui. rents claimed BY the adminstra
ton OF Louisa Browning, heir at law OF a former
u proprietary whilst Maryland was British province.





SUIT against the venerable Charles Carroll Of Car"
rollton, now the only su,viyng sgner OF the Deca-
ration Of Independence, Thy the establishment OF


which, in our opinion. the claim was forever barred
and off,r was brought to an issue IN March last,
: and the Judgment nt the Supreme Court finally
y pronounced against the claimant, upon principles
that apply TO- and protec, every andholder in Mary
d land. The pretended claim of the representatives
t of Mrs Browning, may therefore be considered as
at rest and the andholders OF the state freed from


any further vcxaon thereby.


The high importance OF the principles involved
in the claim as well as It's great amount indu' ed
r us to select two oil the mos, eminent members OF
r the legal profe sion resist il, and we are ath-
ed 10 learn tina, they fully sustained that occasion,
c their exalted regulations"


VI THAT the Peneniary system, as ours is at Pres
ID en-, organized, has tailed in greet degree, as a
means oil refo, maiion both here and elsewhere is
le updenable. Notwithstanding which, every effort
sr should be made 10 periecti ard 10 ascertain "e'h
er our disappointed hopes have ded from ally
~ drfec, in the arrangements Of those establishments
OF or from tho settled depravity Of human naue-de
ID fvins- the institutions of and TO be operated or
ce by the force Of Religion only The system nself
ne i. benevolent one Let Us then make the tx, er
Ne .n Of solitary conhncn eni, as recommended II
at the report Of the committee, and which has bccI
OF e.orted 10 by some OF sister siaes with sangun
re hopes Of success. Solitary confinement a, night
p, after day OF silence and labor is most painful 4
ar those wi,hou, mental resources; more especial.


when the mind i, destitute Of the recollection o


any actions bu, those of wi.kedness.


Should the legislature approve OF the eXperimep


heinz made sufficient number oil small cells coui
er be provided by means be derived from The peni
lis ten,iary itself.


Of We would further recommend TO the General As
to sembly the propriey Of so smending the law as
increase the punishment in all cases of second con
ay vic,ions and that some other punishment than con
,e S,-ment IN the Penitentary be provided for thlr
